author: .vbuterin
content:
The main things that I think people really want post-PoS are:

* Data sharding
* Statelessness + state expiry
* ZK-SNARKing the EVM and other state transitions
* Miscellaneous security upgrades like VDF oracle, proof of custody, etc

Account abstraction (can be done mostly-off-chain with flashbots-like techniques, so it doesn't strictly require consensus changes (!!). And the cost of those changes above being delayed is definitely significantly lower than the cost of the merge being delayed.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is value in *eventually* calcifying the protocol as that gives people long-term confidence in the system (changes bring risk with them).  However, I think this industry is still in its infancy and has a long way to go before it is to the point where calcification makes sense.

author: torfbolt
content: From past experience I would argue that the notion of "this software is finished, we won't ever need to change it again" is often a bad decision. So in my opinion the cost of scheduling something like yearly update slots via an ice age is definitely lower than the risk of premature stagnation. Note that those hardforks can also be of the type "Everything running smoothly here, we'll just push back the ice age".

author: sky.cactus
content: Defaults are powerful, and if the default is "do nothing" then it requires a lot more "effort" to do *something*/*anything*.

author: sky.cactus
content: By making the default "do something", then getting a change (any change) pushed through no longer requires overcoming the power of the default.

content: Yes, I see it like putting scheduled election intervals into the constitution. Nobody forces you to de-elect a good government, but if something needs to change you are glad for the scheduled election.

If one *desires* change, then a default of change is a good idea.

author: torfbolt
content: So are there any further ideas on how to actually build a PoS ice age? Delaying slots looks easy at first sight, but I'm not sure about what stuff implicitly depends on regular slots. And the regular slots are a bit too beautiful to touch them tbh ðŸ™‚

author: torfbolt
content: Invalidating slots might work, but I'm not sure if there is non-gameable randomness around to do so, so that it isn't gameable by the other validators / block proposers.

author: torfbolt
content: But then it doesn't even have to be random. Something like "slot x mod n is invalid", where n is very large initially and then slowly decreasing could work.

author: sky.cactus
content: Simplest solution is to just increase block time.  A more hard-line approach is to just stop block production.

author: torfbolt
content: I think gradually stopping block production is preferable to a hard stop. Maybe just the first block of every epoch, then the first two, and so on

author: potuz
content: I may not be good about following rules but in general I am good at knowing them. And governance issues are explicitly not allowed in this server, so I'll stick to the technical part on how to implement an ICE age. I think PoS allows for a few more variants that weren't there in PoW. Randomly declaring more and more blocks invalid could be very complicated to implement cause you'll have to reinclude transactions and the execution and consensus layers are weakly coupled after the merge. I think changing block time is really hard to implement for clients since clock sync is one of the foundations of the networking stack of PsS. One thing that can be done is to require more and more consecutive justified epochs to declare one to be finalized. This way you can delay finalization without really changing execution at all. Then parties will have to either go back and resort to number of blocks to confirm transactions (knowing that is cheaper in PoS for some players to actually have long chains without them being finalized) or pressure devs to get back to work
